review.title: The Mind Grows Circuits
review.abstract: There is a vast supply of prior art that study models for mental processes. Some studies in psychology and philosophy approach it from an inner perspective in terms of experiences and percepts. Others such as neurobiology or connectionist-machines approach it externally by viewing the mind as complex circuit of neurons where each neuron is a primitive binary circuit. In this paper, we also model the mind as a place where a circuit grows, starting as a collection of primitive components at birth and then builds up incrementally in a bottom up fashion. A new node is formed by a simple composition of prior nodes when we undergo a repeated experience that can be described by that composition. Unlike neural networks, however, these circuits take "concepts" or "percepts" as inputs and outputs. Thus the growing circuits can be likened to a growing collection of lambda expressions that are built on top of one another in an attempt to compress the sensory input as a heuristic to bound its Kolmogorov Complexity.

sections.text: ar Xiv: 120 3.00 88v2 [cs.AI] 17 There is an enormous supply of state of the art research into models of mental processes; some studies in psychology and philosophy approach it from an inner perspective in terms of experiences and perceptions; others such as neurobiology or connectionist machines approach it from the outside, viewing the mind as a complex circuit of neurons, with each neuron being a primitive binary circuit. In this paper, we also model the mind as a place where a circuit grows, starting as a collection of primitive components at birth and then progressively from the bottom up. A new node arises from a simple composition of previous nodes when we go through a repetitive experience that can be described by this composition. Unlike neural networks, however, these circuits take "concepts" or "perceptions" as inputs and outputs. Thus, the growing circuits can be reconstructed with a growing collection of lambda expressions, which can be perfectly matched to another.

sections.heading: 1 Introduction
sections.text: Understanding mental phenomena has been an age-old subject in various disciplines of philosophy [1, 2], psychology [14], ethology [3], cognitive sciences [19], and linguistics [18]. It is also the subject of modern fields such as neuroscience [15] and artificial intelligence [13, 9]. Some of the early studies of psychology and philosophy approach the question by looking at mental phenomena subjectively from the point of view of experiences and perceptions. Others, such as neurobiology or artificial intelligence, approach the subject from the other end by looking at the mind as a neural network [12], where each neuron is a primitive binary circuit. Simplicity theory [4, 5] (and other older works [11]) emphasize the principle of "simplicity" in cognition - using the concept of Kolmogorov complexity [8], it shows that several cognitive functions can be understood as composite concepts that can constitute a certain sensory stimulus.

sections.heading: 3 Concepts grow like circuits hierarchically
sections.text: This is only a matter of time before we arrive at a terminology based on a new concept that is remembered. It is then interpreted as a composition of a small number of previous concepts, as if they were very quickly incorporated into the "fast path." Concepts in the slow path are based on a new concept. The circuits or functions underlying these common concepts can be calculated very quickly as if they were in the "fast path." Concepts in the slow path must be evaluated consciously and slowly. Concepts in the fast path are evaluated automatically, without a conscious experience of computation.The concept graph operations can be described as follows: For each new experience from external events, we must evaluate the components consciously and slowly.

sections.heading: 4 Experiences as learning an ensemble of func-
sections.text: One can compare the formation of concepts with the learning of an ensemble of functions. Let's say there are many functions - and we get certain inputs, pairs of output for each of these functions. Our goal is to learn these functions. In order to distinguish these functions, we will say that these functions have different colors - let's say that the output pairs of the different functions arrive in arbitrary order. A single function can be complex and therefore one cannot learn the function from its examples. But, if these functions form a hierarchy in which the function can be expressed as a simple composition of a few lower functions in the hierarchy, it can be interwoven in arbitrary order. A single function can be complex and therefore one cannot learn the function from its examples.
